text.p: The following are the main stories from Tuesday morning's German newspapers:
- Bavaria political leaders want stronger laws against sexual crimes in wake of sexual attack and murder of seven-year-old girl last week
- Government approves main points of third phase of healthcare reform
- Peter Graf and Joachim Eckardt to remain in jail after court rules against allowing him to be released on bond
- German authorities begin huge probe of undocumented aliens working for domestic companies
- Peter Graf to remain in prison after state court rules against allowing him to post bond
- Russia security advisor Alexander Lebed threatens Germanz and United States with sanctions because of plans for an eastward expansion of NATO

- Daimler-Benz to cut sick pay for workers to 80 percent from 100 percent, Germany's biggest company leads the way with concrete plans from October 1 to reduce sick pay for workers after government legislation passed parliament in September
- Germany to remain firm in its opposition to the sale of International Monetary Fund gold
- Chancellor Helmut Kohl says time plan and criteria for Maastricht criteria for monetary union should not be altered
- Health Minister Horst Seehofer to push further cuts in healthcare costs

- Germany and China put aside their dispute that prompted June postponement of planned July visit of Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel after government had passed a resolution critical of Beijing's policy on Tibet
- Government approves phase three of healthcare reform, patients will have more empowerment, physicians will be obligated to inform patients about their services and fees
- Government and opposition SPD appear to be moving towards compromise on raising child-support money (Kindergeld) in 1997
